content.title: 2026 Predictions: Loyalty, RWAs, x402 & Stablecoins
content.summary: Cuy Sheffield (Head of Crypto, Visa) summarizes four 2026 trends: tokenized loyalty (prediction: $1B tokenized loyalty value by end-2026); RWAs & non‑USD stablecoins as collateral (forecast 5x growth to ~$1.8B); x402 agentic micropayments expanding beyond memecoins (20% real-world volume prediction); and continued growth of stablecoin settlement over VisaNet. Thread includes charts showing rapid RWA/non‑USD stablecoin collateral growth and prior x402 volume spikes.

bullets: Trend 1 — Tokenized loyalty: Brands issued $300B traditional points in 2025; prediction: $1B tokenized loyalty program value by end-2026.
Trend 2 — RWAs & non‑USD stablecoins: On‑chain lending grew to $246B in 2025; current RWA/non‑USD collateral $362M; forecast 5x to ~$1.8B.
Trend 3 — x402 & agentic commerce: x402 saw memecoin-heavy volume in 2025; prediction: 20% of x402 volume will be tied to real-world use cases in 2026.
Trend 4 — Stablecoin settlement: $3.5B annualized stablecoin settlement over VisaNet in 2025; expects continued issuer/acquirer adoption and growth.

The y-axis scales from $0 to $400,000,000. The data shows negligible collateral value throughout 2023 and 2024, followed by a parabolic increase starting in early 2025. By mid-2025, the collateral value exceeds $100 million, and by the end of the period shown, it reaches approximately $360 million. This visualizes the rapid expansion of real-world assets (RWAs) and non-USD stablecoins being used as collateral in the financial ecosystem, serving as a baseline for a predicted 5x growth to $1.8 billion by 2026.

The data highlights the volatile but significant early adoption phase of agentic micropayments.

content.title: Right-for-Wrong-Reasons: Small Models Study
content.summary: DAIR.AI highlights a new paper showing a hidden reliability crisis in 7–9B models: 50–69% of correct answers contain flawed reasoning. Analysis of 10,734 traces across Llama-3-8B, Mistral-7B, and Qwen-2.5-7B introduces the Reasoning Integrity Score (RIS). Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) improves reasoning (Cohen's d = 0.23–0.93; calculation errors down 7.6%), while self-critique prompts harm performance (d = -0.14 to -0.33). Authors distilled a lightweight neural verifier (0.86 F1, 100× speedup). Paper link and DAIR academy course provided.

bullets: 50–69% of correct outputs from 7–9B models show fundamentally flawed reasoning (Right-for-Wrong-Reasons).
Reasoning Integrity Score (RIS) introduced as a process-based metric; validated with inter-rater agreement.
RAG substantially improves reasoning integrity (Cohen's d = 0.23–0.93); reduces calculation errors by 7.6%.
Self-critique/meta-cognitive prompts degrade small-model performance (d = -0.14 to -0.33, 'pseudo-reflection').
Study analyzed 10,734 reasoning traces across Llama-3-8B, Mistral-7B, Qwen-2.5-7B on math, multi-hop QA, commonsense.
Authors distilled a neural verifier achieving 0.86 F1 and ~100× speedup vs LLM judges for real-time trust checks.
Recommendation: adopt process-based verification as a standard safety layer when deploying small-model agents.

images.title: Right-for-Wrong-Reasons: Process Verification for Trustworthy Agents Research Paper
images.description: The first page of a research paper titled 'When Small Models Are Right for Wrong Reasons: Process Verification for Trustworthy Agents' by Laksh Advani. The research identifies a critical reliability crisis in small language models (7-9B parameters) such as Llama-3-8B, Mistral-7B, and Qwen-2.5-7B, where 50-69% of correct answers are derived from fundamentally flawed reasoning, termed 'Right-for-Wrong-Reasons' (RWR). The study introduces the Reasoning Integrity Score (RIS) and analyzes 10,734 reasoning traces across mathematical reasoning, multi-hop QA, and commonsense reasoning. Key findings indicate that Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) improves reasoning integrity (Cohen's d = 0.23-0.93) and reduces errors by 7.6%, while meta-cognitive interventions like self-critique often harm performance (d = -0.14 to -0.33). The paper also presents a distilled neural classifier for verification achieving a 0.86 F1-score with a 100x speedup. Actionable guidance includes prioritizing RAG for fact-grounded tasks and implementing process-based verification as a safety layer for autonomous agents.

content.title: Thogard: Monad Foundation — Critique & Thesis
content.summary: Long-form critique and bullish thesis on the Monad Foundation. Author criticizes airdrop allocation (favoring non-technical insiders), the “no king making” policy that mutes standout native apps, and ineffective incentive programs. Provides concrete tokenomic claims: Foundation stakes ~90% of staked MON, captures ~85% emissions, staked supply ~15% (staking yield ~12.5%), and emissions of 25 MON/400ms (~2% inflation). Argues the Foundation functions like a central bank and can use staking to modulate yields, TVL, and capital flows.

bullets: Airdrop favored BD/community/retail activity over technical contributions and research.
Technical work, developer evangelism, and builder-focused outreach were reportedly under-rewarded.
Author argues this bias discourages top-tier builders and misaligns long-term ecosystem incentives.
Quote: “Show me the incentives and I’ll show you the results.”
Foundation's refusal to highlight winners homogenizes app messaging and hides unique native features.
Kuru’s flip orders and CLOB innovations are seldom amplified by foundation channels, per author.
Silence leads VCs to perceive Monad apps as weak, reducing external investment interest.
Author says goal should be enabling winners while allowing competition to dethrone them.
Monad Momentum is criticized as ineffective; few participants rank among top native apps.
Author asserts consistent wealth-generating events (airdrops) are crucial to drive native adoption.
Imported apps currently outrank native apps on key metrics, per the author’s observation.
Claims: Foundation stakes ~90% of staked MON and receives ~85% of emissions (commission-adjusted).
Staked supply ~15%, yielding ~12.5% net-of-commission; emissions cited as 25 MON per 400ms (~2% inflation).
Foundation can increase/decrease its staked share to lower/raise staking APR, influencing TVL and capital flows.
Author views this control as a unique, potentially constructive central‑bank‑like lever for DeFi.

content.title: Edge Series #43: ZEC vs CYPH; HNT buyback pause
content.summary: Chaos Labs Edge Series #43 highlights a sharp divergence: ZEC surged ~41.2% over 30 days (224.7% over 90d) while Cypherpunk Technologies ($CYPH, ~$64M) gained 1.8% (47.9% over 90d). Cypherpunk doesn't disclose NAV, so equity-specific factors likely drive the spread. Separate note: Helium paused HNT buybacks to preserve treasury and redeploy capital toward network growth; market reaction was muted (HNT ~$1.58, +1.5% 24h, trusted spot volume +141% week).

bullets: Zcash (ZEC) outpaced Cypherpunk shares: ZEC +41.2% (30d), +224.7% (90d); CYPH +1.8% (30d), +47.9% (90d).
Cypherpunk Technologies trades near $1.13 with ~$64M market cap and $3.1M volume (charted by Chaos Labs).
Cypherpunk does not disclose NAV, preventing premium/discount calculation; shares likely influenced by equity-specific factors.
Helium CEO said HNT buybacks are paused to conserve treasury and redirect spending toward network growth.
Market reaction muted: HNT ~$1.58 (+1.5% 24h, +6.5% 7d), still down ~76% YoY per tweet.
Trusted spot trading volume rose ~141% week; removing buybacks reduces recurring demand, future price tied to effectiveness of redirected spending.

content.title: GMX buyback math vs market pricing
content.summary: Author argues GMX is repurchasing ~13% of supply annually at $8.31 after a $86M September hack. Cites $2.1B weekly volume, $15.4M yearly revenue, and a 5.6x sales multiple. At November buyback pace they'd remove the float in 339 days; market pricing, the author says, overstates permanent damage.

bullets: Claims GMX buys back 13% of supply annually at $8.31 after September's $86M hack.
Says protocol is doing $2.1B weekly volume and $15.4M annual revenue, trading at 5.6x sales.

projects.short_description: Ethereum is a decentralized, open-source blockchain platform that enables smart contracts and dApps through its Turing-complete Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). It transitioned to Proof-of-Stake for energy efficiency and security, and scales via Layer 2 solutions and upgrades like Dencun and the upcoming Fusaka and Pectra. Ethereum boasts the largest ecosystem for DeFi, NFTs, and AI agents, with growing institutional interest and ETF approvals solidifying its foundational role in the decentralized web.

Large holders deposited ~$2.4B to Binance in the prior week, including ~$1.07B in Ether, signaling potential selling pressure.
Coinbase forecasts 2026 will see spot‑ETF growth, stablecoin settlement, tokenization and clearer regulation, accelerating institutional demand.

CoinDesk analysis says Ethereum closed 2025 with stronger institutional adoption and Layer‑2 interoperability, positioning the network for a potential DeFi resurgence in 2026.
Grayscale's ETHE distributed $0.083178 per share in staking rewards for Oct 6–Dec 31, 2025, payable Jan 6, 2026, marking the first U.S. Ethereum ETP to pass staking rewards.
SlowMist: $2.935B stolen in 2025 across 200 incidents, rising attack sophistication, and increased AML freezes; recommends stronger audits and AI monitoring.

projects.short_description: Solana is a high-performance, open-source blockchain designed for scalable decentralized applications and financial services. It leverages a unique monolithic architecture and is transitioning to the Alpenglow consensus protocol for industry-leading transaction speeds, low costs, and sub-second finality. Its rapidly expanding ecosystem spans DeFi, NFTs, gaming, DePIN, and Real World Assets, attracting both retail and institutional adoption. Recent upgrades and emerging Layer 2 solutions further enhance its throughput and reliability, positioning it as a competitive alternative for global on-chain economic activity.

recent_developments.development_text: Grayscale files to rename its vehicle to “Grayscale Solana Staking ETF,” updating trust documents to position the product toward staking exposure for SOL.
ChainSecurity audits Keel's SVM ALM Controller, the gateway for $USDS liquidity on Solana and engine behind a $500M tokenization initiative.
Solflare launches Solflare AI alpha, an in‑wallet LLM assistant for intent‑based DeFi automation on Solana with natural‑language trades.
Crypto ETP inflows in 2025 totaled ~$47.2B; Solana ETP inflows rose ~1,000% to ~$3.6B as altcoins led flows, contributing to ~$180B global crypto ETP AUM.
Dexter launches x402 v2 native cross‑chain bridge between Solana and Base, enabling trustless swaps between the two chains.
Helius released getTransactionsForAddress RPC for Solana, providing server‑side filtering, pagination, and up to ~20x faster transaction history queries.
CoinDesk reports Solana hardened infrastructure in 2025, increased block space ~25%, and prepared Alpenglow to reduce finality toward ~1 second.
Jito/IBRL launches the IBRL Explorer, a public tool that measures Solana validator block‑building and transaction‑packing behavior.

Parcl launched 'Parcl Deal Flow,' simplifying real estate investing with Market Discovery, Daily Appraisals, Equity Accounts, and a Deal Analysis Tool.
Parcl V3 is live on Solana, providing an upgraded platform for liquid real estate exposure.

Virtuals' SeeSaw recorded 500,000 tasks in two months. Virtuals signals a Q1 2026 inflection for embodied agents with early ACP integrations.
Virtuals Butler adds conversational prediction markets on X: users can tag @Butler_Agent in replies or DM Butler to access prediction markets directly in-feed.
Chromia integrated with Virtuals' Agent Commerce Protocol to provide decentralized relational data primitives for agent memory and verifiable storage.

projects.short_description: DoubleZero is building a decentralized physical infrastructure layer (N1) to provide high-performance, low-latency networking for blockchains. It utilizes a dual-ring fiber optic architecture with edge filtering hardware (FPGAs) to significantly reduce latency and increase throughput, addressing public internet bottlenecks. The project aims to enable unprecedented scalability and security for distributed systems, initially focusing on Solana and planning expansion to other high-performance chains. Its native 2Z token powers network access, contributor rewards, and security.

recent_developments.development_text: Corvus Labs operates a DoubleZero-connected validator running full Firedancer on Solana mainnet, improving validator performance and network robustness.
Three new DoubleZero mainnet‑beta routes went live: CHI↔LAX 75Gbps, LON↔FRA 100Gbps, and SEA↔SLC 100Gbps, expanding dedicated low‑latency fiber capacity.
DoubleZero joined the Blockchain Association to participate in U.S. policy discussions, citing its SEC No‑Action Letter.
DoubleZero added 400Gbps to mainnet-beta via Distributed Global, expanding dedicated low‑latency bandwidth with four new 100Gbps links.
DoubleZero warns of widespread impersonator accounts; advises community to verify identities and exercise caution against phishing attempts.

projects.short_description: Monad is a high-performance, EVM-compatible Layer 1 blockchain designed for extreme scalability and speed. It aims to process over 10,000 transactions per second with 0.8-second finality, utilizing innovations like optimistic parallel execution, deferred execution, and a custom BFT consensus, MonadBFT. With full Ethereum bytecode compatibility, it enables seamless migration for dApps and developers. Having secured over $225 million in funding, Monad launched its public testnet in February 2025 and its mainnet on November 24, 2025, actively building a diverse ecosystem.

recent_developments.development_text: Safe{Wallet} deploys on 14 new networks, adding Smart Account support for Monad and extending Safe smart‑account standards to the Monad ecosystem.
Parsec launches 'Monad Agent', a monitoring and ecosystem directory platform providing dynamic project updates, an ecosystem feed, charts, and chat.
Monad launches "Monad Momentum," an incentives matching grants program to fund user‑acquisition campaigns for Monad mainnet apps.
Noma Protocol deployed to Monad mainnet; NOMA token presale is live (Dec 29, 2025–Feb 27, 2026), hard cap 100M MON and initial liquidity paired to MON.
Onramp Money adds fiat on‑ramp support to buy USDC on the Monad network, enabling purchases via local rails and bank transfers across 30+ countries.
GMX launches MON/USD perpetual market across Ethereum, Arbitrum, BNB Chain, and Base, enabling long/short positions and LP incentives via GLV.
mEDGE (Midas-issued token) is live on Monad and supported as collateral on Gearbox, with USDC liquidity available via the Edge Capital Management vault.
Monad announces onboarding of MapleStory Universe, beginning with an NXPC integration and signaling further collaborations.

projects.short_description: deBridge is a cross-chain interoperability protocol facilitating seamless asset and message transfers across over 30 blockchains. It employs an intent-based, 0-TVL architecture with a decentralized network of validators and solvers for secure, high-speed, and capital-efficient transactions. deBridge integrated Monad (EVM-compatible L1) as Day‑1 IaaS partner, enabling cross-chain asset transfers and liquidity movement for $MON.

projects.short_description: Jito is a Solana-based protocol offering MEV-enhanced liquid staking through JitoSOL, which accrues both staking and MEV rewards. It provides infrastructure like the Jito-Solana client and Block Engine for efficient MEV capture and distribution, and StakeNet for decentralized validator management. content.text:
Market discussions are currently dominated by **Bitcoin's short-squeeze rally**, institutional scaling on **Solana**, and the rapid maturation of the **AI agent economy**. Traditional narratives around protocol novelty are being replaced by rigorous analysis of **onchain revenue** and **resilience**, especially as major supply events like the **Hyperliquid ($HYPE)** unlock approach.

### Macro & Asset Dynamics
Bitcoin is testing the **$93k-$94k range** after a squeeze-driven rebound fueled by geopolitical shocks and weekend liquidity gaps. Technical conviction is shifting toward a mean-reversion target of **$104k–$107k**, supported by massive institutional accumulation in the options market. Specifically, traders spent over **$15M in premiums** on Jan/Feb call spreads, with heavy volume on the **$98k and $100k strikes**.

<post post_id="331669" summary="TradFi and native whales spent $15M on BTC calls, signaling a momentum play toward $100k." card_type="post"></post>

Solana's institutional narrative is decoupling from the broader altcoin market as **Solana ETFs surpassed $1B in combined AUM** this week. **Bitwise (BSOL)** leads with $681M, followed by Grayscale and Fidelity. This influx of regulated capital coincides with Solana capturing **$1.3B in YTD revenue**, outperforming Ethereum’s $524M and establishing a clear dominance in blockspace demand.

<post post_id="330709" summary="Solana ETFs hit $1B AUM, with Bitwise leading the institutional charge." card_type="post"></post>

### Onchain Revenue & Ecosystem Shifts
**Hyperliquid** remains a high-conviction topic as it cements its position as the second-highest revenue-generating protocol ($816M YTD). The **HIP-3 tradexyz DEX** reported over **$12.17B in total volume** and $1.7M in fees, though the market is braced for volatility ahead of the **January 6, 2026, token unlock**.

<post post_id="331026" summary="Hyperliquid’s tradexyz DASHBOARD reveals $12B+ volume and significant fee generation." card_type="post"></post>

In the DeFi sector, **Aave** is seeing a massive divergence between fundamentals and price. Lending deposits grew **61.2% YoY** while the token price dropped **52.1%**, leading to calls that the market is severely underpricing its infrastructure potential. Similarly, **Arbitrum** is gaining attention for its treasury diversification, which has grown to **$105M** by incorporating RWAs like **BlackRock’s BUIDL** and stablecoins.

### AI Agents & Agentic Commerce
The AI agent sector is pivoting from novelty to production-ready tools. **Virtuals Protocol ($VIRTUAL)** surged **24%** following the announcement of its three-tier agent framework (**Pegasus, Unicorn, Titan**). The narrative is shifting toward "Agentic GDP," where agents like those built on **Virtuals** or **Recall** use vision-capable models to outperform standard LLMs in onchain trading contests.

<post post_id="331852" summary="ETH trading contest results show vision-capable LLMs significantly outperforming text-only models." card_type="post"></post>

Emerging standards like **x402** for agentic micropayments and the launch of **AMI Labs** by former Meta AI chief Yann LeCun are being framed as the "Practicality Threshold" for 2026. This is reinforced by **Parcl’s** new partnership with **Polymarket** to power real-estate prediction markets, signaling a move toward deeper integration between AI-driven data and onchain execution.

content.title: State of Crypto Cards: 2023–2025 Report
content.summary: Memento Research's on‑chain report finds 2025 was a breakout year for crypto cards: monthly deposits and spending scaled exponentially, monthly transaction volume topped ~$120M and MAU reached ~40k by Oct‑2025. Stablecoins (USDT/USDC) account for nearly all deposits. Rain-based card infrastructure drove the 2025 deposit surge and market-share shift; Gnosis Pay cardholders transact most frequently and skew to higher monthly spend. Chains expanding deposits include Ethereum, Polygon and several L2s. Report flags privacy risks, concentration in card-as-a-service providers, and 2026 focus shifting toward interchange economics and credit-adjacent products.

bullets: 2025 marked exponential growth: monthly tx volume > $120M and MAU ≈ 39–40k (Oct ’25).
Nearly 100% of deposited collateral is USD stablecoins; USDT led early, USDC rose to parity.
Rain-based cards (card-as-service) captured most 2025 deposit growth and market share.
Gnosis Pay cardholders show highest activity (~28 transactions/month) and skew to larger spend bands.
Deposit rails expanded from Ethereum to Polygon, Base, Arbitrum, Optimism and Solana.
Privacy/doXXability: on‑chain spending exposes behavioral linkages and CEX trails.
Concentration risk: many programs depend on a few card-as-a-service providers (single point of failure).
Merchant and chargeback friction: high‑risk categories face stricter controls and AML scrutiny.
2026 dynamics: growth will hinge on interchange economics, routing efficiency, profitability, and credit features.

images.title: Monthly Crypto Card Collateral Deposits 2023-2025
images.description: A stacked bar chart showing the growth of monthly collateral deposits by crypto card programs from December 2023 to October 2025, measured in USD millions. The chart highlights exponential growth starting in early 2025. Total monthly deposits rose from approximately $50 million in December 2023 to nearly $275 million by October 2025. The data is categorized by card programs: Rain-based Cards (light green), WireX Card (dark green), RedotPay (light blue), Cypher Card (medium green), Holyheld Card (orange), MetaMask Card (dark blue), and Gnosis Pay Card (bright green). Rain-based cards, which include EtherFi Cash, KAST, and Avalanche Card, emerged as the dominant category in 2025, driving the majority of the deposit surge. WireX Card and RedotPay also maintained significant market shares. The chart indicates a clear trend of increasing capital commitment to crypto-linked payment solutions over the two-year period.

images.title: Monthly New Crypto Card Users Growth 2023-2025
images.description: A stacked bar chart illustrating the growth of monthly new users for crypto cards from December 2023 to October 2025. The chart categorizes users into three groups: MetaMask Card, Rain-based Cards, and Gnosis Pay Card. Growth remained relatively flat below 1,000 new monthly users until August 2024. A significant upward trend began in late 2024, with a major breakout in December 2024 reaching approximately 4,500 new users. Throughout 2025, the volume of new users scaled significantly, peaking in August 2025 at roughly 12,000 new users. By October 2025, the monthly new user count (N) stood at 11.3k. Rain-based cards, which include providers like EtherFi Cash and Avalanche Card, represent the dominant share of this growth. MetaMask Card adoption also saw a notable increase starting in late 2024. The data indicates that the rise in Monthly Active Users (MAU) is primarily driven by a sharp increase in new-to-crypto-card users, suggesting successful early onboarding.

content.title: Yann LeCun exits Meta, launches AMI Labs
content.summary: Thread summarizes Yann LeCun’s departure from Meta after public clashes over strategy: Zuckerberg bought Scale AI and made Alexandr Wang LeCun’s boss; LeCun called Wang “inexperienced,” said Meta manipulated Llama 4 benchmarks, and refused to stop criticizing LLM-only approaches. LeCun is launching AMI Labs aiming for $3B valuation and a “baby version” within a year. Images show LeCun’s LinkedIn announcement and a news screenshot.

bullets: LeCun — Turing Award winner and long-time Meta AI chief — left after internal disputes over Meta’s AI direction.
Zuckerberg spent $14B on Scale AI, hired Alexandr Wang to run a new Superintelligence Lab, and made Wang LeCun’s boss.
LeCun publicly called Wang “young” and “inexperienced” and said researchers shouldn’t be directed in that way.
LeCun alleges Meta “fudged” Llama 4 benchmark results and lost confidence in people involved, sidelining the GenAI team.
He’s forming AMI Labs (target $3B valuation), plans a ‘baby version’ in a year; LinkedIn post and news screenshot attached.

content.title: Ray Dalio: 2025 markets reflection
content.summary: Ray Dalio reviews 2025 macro outcomes: currency depreciation drove the year's biggest moves (gold +65% vs. dollar), US stocks outperformed in dollar terms but underperformed vs. non‑US equities and gold, and bonds fared poorly in hard‑money terms. He links returns to fiscal/monetary reflation, productivity, politics (US policies, deglobalization), geopolitics, climate, and AI. Concludes equity risk premia are low, expected long‑term equity returns are weak (~4.7%), and positions should consider currency hedging, diversification, and careful allocation.

bullets: All fiat currencies fell vs. gold; gold rose ~65% in dollar terms and was the best major market of 2025.
Dollar moved: -0.3% vs JPY, -4% vs RMB, -12% vs EUR, -13% vs CHF, -39% vs gold.
S&P500 returned 18% in dollars but -28% in gold‑money terms; currency lens materially changes perceived returns.
US equities: earnings +12%, P/E expansion ~5%; Magnificent 7 earnings +22%; rest of S&P earnings +9%.
Non‑US equities outperformed US: Europe +23%, China +21%, UK +19%, Japan +10%; EM equities +34%.
10‑yr UST returned ~9% in dollar terms but deeply negative in gold terms; debt assets unattractive in real terms.
Primary drivers: money/debt/markets/economy, politics, geopolitics, acts of nature (climate), and technology (AI).
Reflationary fiscal/monetary policy cut discount rates, supporting long‑duration assets; illiquid markets (VC/PE/RE) lagged.
Valuations stretched: equity expected return ~4.7% vs bond yields ~4.9%; low equity risk premiums imply limited upside.
US policies (Trump admin) pushed stimulative, industrial, and protectionist agenda, increasing polarization and capital concentration.
Shift from multilateralism to unilateralism raised conflict risk, military spending, protectionism, and capital reallocation toward gold and non‑US assets.
Dalio expects political battles over wealth/inflation to intensify, affecting markets and elections ahead.
Hedge to your least‑risk currency mix; currency hedging materially alters returns and risk.
Favor diversification into non‑US markets and hard assets; be cautious on long‑duration credit and illiquid assets.
Dalio offers courses (Dalio Market Principles) for deeper methodology and portfolio construction.

Platform spent 18,807.58 $HYPE (~$494,690 at current price) on tickers.

The top section displays key performance indicators: a total trading volume of $12.17 billion, 36,688 unique traders, $1.70 million in trading fees collected, 5,922,729 total trades, and 43,308 liquidations. The 'XYZ Trading Volume Over Time' chart uses teal bars for daily volume and a red line for cumulative volume, showing a significant surge in activity starting mid-November with daily peaks near $500 million and cumulative volume surpassing $12 billion. content.title: Vitalik: Ethereum's purpose is resilience
content.summary: Vitalik revisits the "Trustless Manifesto" claim that Ethereum's goal is to set people free, arguing Ethereum should prioritize resilience (minimizing catastrophic failures, censorship, deplatforming) over marginal gains in efficiency or convenience. Resilience equates to digital sovereignty: permissionless, decentralized blockspace that remains accessible despite political, infrastructure, or developer risk. He frames Ethereum's unique value as providing robust, permissionless blockspace rather than competing with Silicon Valley on UX or marginal performance tweaks.

bullets: Efficiency/convenience improve average-case UX (lower latency, higher yields) but can’t beat centralized incumbents.
Ethereum’s primary role should be resilience: reduce risk of total loss, censorship, or deplatforming.
Resilience means access anywhere despite developer abandonment, infrastructure outages, geopolitical or cyber conflict.
Resilience is analogous to sovereignty — reducing external dependencies that can be revoked.

content.title: 24h Crypto Signals — BTC 92k Squeeze Analysis
content.summary: Author analyzes the Jan 5 price rebound (BTC ~ $92k) as likely a short-squeeze rather than a fresh trend. Identifies three structural drivers: Venezuela geopolitical shock raising volatility, weekend liquidity–driven squeezes, and resurfacing mid‑term narratives (regulatory compression, prediction markets, token unlocks). Key data: BTC $92k (+1.86%), ETH ~$3,200 (+1%), 24h liquidations ≈ $191M (shorts ≈ $158M). Thesis: trend continuation depends on post-open ETF flows; HYPE unlock (2026-01-06) and Jupiter distribution are near-term supply events to monitor.

bullets: BTC reached ~$92k; author views move as squeeze-driven rebound, not confirmed trend.
Three structural drivers: geopolitical shock (Venezuela), weekend liquidity squeeze, resurging mid-term narratives.
24h liquidations ≈ $191M; shorts ≈ $158M — explains fast, lift-style rebound.
ETF flows matter: data uses 1/2 flows; continuation after US open will decide sustainability.
Early event risks: HYPE token unlock (2026-01-06) and Jupiter 'Jupuary' distribution may create supply shocks.

content.title: BTC 1W 25Δ Risk Reversal Flips Positive
content.summary: Laevitas reports BTC 1-week 25-delta risk reversal flipped positive today, rising from −1.8 vols to +0.86 vols (calls ~0.86 vol points richer than puts). The 1-month 25Δ RR recovered from ~−2 vols to −0.3 vols but remains negative. Attached Deribit chart (Dec 8–Jan 5) shows a cross-tenor rise, signaling waning put skew and growing demand for upside exposure.

bullets: 1W 25Δ RR flipped from −1.8 vols to +0.86 vols; calls trading ~0.86 vol points richer than puts.
1M 25Δ RR recovered from ~−2.0 vols to ~−0.3 vols, still slightly negative.
Chart (Deribit data, Dec 8–Jan 5) shows upward trend across tenors, moving from deep negative toward zero/positive.
Implication: lower cost of downside protection and increased demand for upside/call exposure; skew moved from bearish toward neutral/bullish.

images.title: BTC Deribit 25-Delta Risk Reversal Chart
images.description: A line chart from Laevitas displaying the 25-delta risk reversal (RR) for Bitcoin (BTC) on Deribit between December 8 and January 5. The chart tracks several timeframes (tenors): 1-week (1W), 1-month (1M), 2-month (2M), 3-month (3M), 6-month (6M), and 1-year (1Y). The Y-axis measures the RR value in vols, ranging from -8 to 2. Initially, in early December, all tenors are deeply negative (between -4 and -7), indicating a strong put skew where downside protection is more expensive than upside calls. Over the period, there is a clear upward trend across all tenors. By January 5, the 1W RR (red line) flips into positive territory, reaching approximately +0.86 vols, signaling that calls have become more expensive than puts. The 1M RR (blue line) also shows a significant recovery from -6 to approximately -0.3 vols. Longer-dated tenors (6M and 1Y) show a steadier rise but remain negative, ending near -2.5. This cross-tenor recovery indicates waning bearish sentiment and growing demand for upside exposure.

content.title: UMA: Polymarket New Year Proposal Stats
content.summary: UMA reports operational metrics from Polymarket's end-of-2025 market resolution: 1,175 proposals submitted between Jan 1 12–2 AM ET, with ~$880k in proposal bonds locked simultaneously. 15 proposals were disputed (1.2%), only 3 deemed incorrect (0.26%). Heavy initial burst—500 proposals in 12:00–12:05 AM and 226 in 12:05–12:10 AM—then normalized. UMA frames this as evidence of fast response, well-capitalized proposers, and scalability.

bullets: 1,175 proposals submitted on Jan 1 between 12:00–2:00 AM ET.
Approximately $880k in proposal bonds locked at once during the peak.
15 proposals disputed (1.2%); only three incorrect (0.26%).
500 proposals occurred in 12:00–12:05 AM; 226 in 12:05–12:10 AM.
UMA interprets results as fast response, well-capitalized proposers, and scalable design.

content.title: US equity dominance — data and charts
content.summary: Eric Balchunas shares @psarofagis' pushback against claims US exceptionalism ended after 2025: S&P rose ~18% in 2025, yet $12T of global ETF assets remain parked in US markets (≈5x any other country). Bloomberg Intelligence charts show U.S. AUM ~ $11.1T and long-term SPY outperformance versus EFA, illustrating a decade-long performance and capital gap.

bullets: Tweet highlights ~ $12 trillion of global ETF assets parked in U.S. markets — about 5× any other country.
Bloomberg Intelligence AUM chart shows U.S. ETF AUM rising to ~$11.1T by early 2025, far above peers.
Author argues a single year (2025’s +18%) doesn’t erase decades of U.S. capital advantages.
Cumulative-return chart (SPY vs EFA) shows clear divergence starting ~2014, with SPY much higher.
Tweet cites a 174-percentage-point lead of U.S. vs international equities built over a decade.
Point: 2025 was strong globally, but long-term U.S. outperformance and capital concentration remain intact.

images.title: Global ETF Assets under Management by Region (1999-2025)
images.description: A line chart from Bloomberg Intelligence titled 'Assets under Management' tracking the growth of ETF assets from 1999 to early 2025 across several regions: U.S., China, Eurozone, Global, International, and Japan. The x-axis represents time in years, and the y-axis represents AUM in trillions of dollars (USD). The U.S. market, represented by a yellow line, shows exponential growth, reaching approximately $11.1 trillion by 2025. This far exceeds all other categories. The legend provides specific values as of the end of the period: U.S. at 11.1T, Global at 2T (blue line), International at 1.7T (pink line), Japan at 757.3B (beige line), China at 704B (white line), and Eurozone at 294.8B (orange line). The chart highlights a massive and widening gap in capital concentration between the U.S. equity markets and the rest of the world over the last 25 years.

images.title: SPY vs EFA Performance Comparison 2011-2023
images.description: A line chart comparing the cumulative performance of SPY (S&P 500 ETF Trust) and EFA (iShares MSCI EAFE ETF) from August 31, 2011, to August 31, 2023. The white line represents SPY, and the blue line represents EFA. The Y-axis measures percentage growth, ranging from 0% to 400%. SPY shows a significant upward trend, starting near 25% and reaching a peak of approximately 360% in late 2021 before settling around 300% by late 2023. In contrast, EFA shows much more modest growth and higher volatility, starting around 50%, dipping below 25% multiple times between 2014 and 2017, peaking at roughly 150% in 2018, and ending the period near 110%. The chart illustrates the substantial outperformance of US equities (SPY) compared to international developed markets (EFA) over the twelve-year period, with the performance gap widening dramatically after 2017.

content.title: 2026 Outlook: Crypto & AI Themes
content.summary: Cuy Sheffield lays out eight interlocking themes for 2026 where crypto and AI shift from novelty to production: crypto moving toward infrastructure and payments, stablecoins as clear utility wins, distribution and compliance matter more than protocol novelty, AI agents as workflow tools (not fully autonomous), trust and systems engineering as the core bottlenecks, and programmable, agent-native payments emerging (example: x402). Practical framing prioritizes reliability, governance, and distribution over spectacle.

bullets: Crypto and AI crossed a practicality threshold; winning tech must work reliably in real systems, not just in theory.
Value shifts from speculation toward infrastructure use cases, especially settlement and payments.
Stablecoins offer objective utility — faster, cheaper, globally composable money for institutions and products.
Distribution, regulatory trust, and existing customer relationships now matter more than protocol novelty.
AI agents succeed when embedded as supervised workflow tools; trust, grounding, and systems engineering enable production usage.

content.title: BTC market structure: $104–107K target
content.summary: Crypto_McKenna outlines a BTC technical thesis: market-structure break at $90.336K, a decisive break above the 2025 open and Dec 25 high targets prices north of $100K, with a key resistance/mean-revert zone at $104K–$107K (3D Kijun). She favors putting risk on for an intermediate rally, expects a sell-off near $104–107K but not new lows, and anticipates a structural higher low then continuation toward mid-term targets.

bullets: Clear market-structure break at $90,336 supports short-term bullish conviction.
Break above 2025 open and Dec 25 high would make targets north of $100K likely.
Key resistance and expected mean-revert area sits at $104K–$107K (previous bearish MS break).
Author expects intermediate rally then sell-off at $104–107K, forming a higher low instead of new lows.
3D Kijun-sen sits near $103–104K; current price ≈10% below that level.
Charts show RSI bearish divergences and a 3D trend box labeled 'Bearish'.
Some projections show potential pullback toward $80K–$88K, but author still calls for risk-on exposure now.

images.title: Bitcoin 3D Technical Analysis Chart with Ichimoku Cloud and $104K Target
images.description: A 3-day (3D) candlestick chart for BTC/USD on Coinbase illustrating a technical analysis thesis. The price is currently at $93,079.23, positioned above the Ichimoku Cloud (Kumo) after a recent bounce. A key horizontal resistance level is identified at $103,474.55, which aligns with the 3D Kijun-sen (red line). The top panel displays an RSI indicator with marked bullish and bearish divergences. The bottom panels include a volume-weighted oscillator and a trend momentum indicator showing a shift toward bullish momentum. The chart highlights a market structure break and targets a mean-reversion to the Kijun-sen level as a primary objective.

content.title: Recall: Vision LLMs Outperform on ETH Trading
content.summary: Recall reports results from an ETH trading contest comparing vision-capable LLMs against data-rich LLMs. Vision models took 3 of the top 4 places. Across ~2,000 trades, 63.1% were "well-timed." High reversal rates (>50% spikes) drove a cumulative fee drag ≈0.35%, costing roughly 4% of winners' gains. Recall suggests cleaner, more relevant inputs (chart visuals) can enable faster, better trading decisions.

bullets: Vision models outperformed data-access models — occupying 3 of the top 4 final PnL positions.
Contest analyzed ~2,000 ETH trades; overall 'well-timed' trade rate was 63.1% (avg buy +0.18%, avg sell +0.17%).
Flip-flop (reversal) spikes frequently exceeded 50%, producing a cumulative fee drag of ~0.35%.
Recall estimates indecision-related churning cost ~4% of a winner's gains in a contest decided by single-digit returns.
Key takeaway: giving models cleaner, more relevant inputs (charts) may beat feeding all available market data.

images.title: LLM Performance Comparison in ETH Trading Contest
images.description: A line chart tracking the cumulative percentage returns of nine different Large Language Models (LLMs) during an Ethereum (ETH) trading contest from December 29th to January 5th. The chart distinguishes between vision-capable models and standard data-rich models. As of the final data point on January 5th at 21:58, the performance rankings are: gemini 3 pro vision (7.24%), grok-4 eth (6.87%), sonnet 4.5 vision (6.23%), grok 4 vision (4.18%), sonnet 4.5 eth (3.87%), deepseek 3.2 eth (3.79%), gemini 3 pro (3.45%), gpt-5.2 vision (2.28%), and gpt-5.2 eth (2.27%). The data indicates a sharp upward trend for most models starting around January 3rd. Notably, vision-capable models occupy three of the top four positions, supporting the insight that visual chart interpretation leads to superior trading outcomes compared to text-only data processing. The y-axis scales from -1.64% to 9.84% cumulative return.

images.title: Trade Timing Quality Distribution for ETH Trading
images.description: A histogram titled 'Trade Timing Quality' displaying the timing score distribution by trade direction (Buy vs. Sell). The chart shows that 63.1% of trades were 'well-timed,' with an Average Buy score of +0.18% and an Average Sell score of +0.17%. The data set includes 911 Buy trades (green bars) and 1,082 Sell trades (red bars). The x-axis represents the Timing Score, where positive values indicate good timing, ranging from -2.5% to 3.0%. The y-axis represents Frequency, peaking at nearly 300 for scores just above 0.0%. A dashed grey line marks the zero point, while a dashed orange line indicates the positive shift in the distribution's center, confirming that the majority of trades captured positive price movement relative to their execution time.

bullets: Stacked-area chart shows treasury value rising from ≈$58M (Feb 2025) to ≈$105M (Jan 2026).
Notable steady growth from May–Aug 2025 and a pronounced spike in November 2025.
Portfolio is diversified: stablecoins (USDC, USDT, GHO, USDM), RWAs (BUIDL, TBILL, USTB).

content.title: BTC options: coordinated buy-side flows Jan 2026
content.summary: Deribit Insights reports coordinated TradFi + native buy-side BTC option activity early Jan 2026: ~$15M premium spent on Jan–Feb calls and call spreads around a ~93k spot. Specific trades include Jan16 94k x1k, Jan30 98k x2k, Jan 96–105k spread x750 and Feb27 100k x2k. bullets: Tracked ~$15M premium bought across Jan–Feb calls and Jan call spreads versus ~93k spot.
Notable buys: Jan16 94k x1k; Jan30 98k x2k; Jan 96–105k spread x750; Feb27 100k x2k.

images.title: BTC ATM Constant Maturities Implied Volatility Chart
images.description: A line chart from Amberdata illustrating the At-The-Money (ATM) Constant Maturities for Bitcoin (BTC) from December 29, 2025, to January 6, 2026. The chart tracks implied volatility (IV) for tenors ranging from 1 day to 180 days (ATM 1, 2, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30, 60, 90, 180). The Y-axis measures implied volatility percentage from 35% to 50%. In late December, longer-dated maturities (90 and 180 days) maintain higher IV levels around 42-43%, while shorter-dated maturities trade lower between 36-39%. A notable trend begins on January 2nd, where implied volatility across all maturities starts to rise. By January 5th, a significant spike occurs, particularly in shorter-dated maturities (ATM 1, 2, 3, and 7), which surge to peak levels between 45% and 47%, converging with or exceeding the longer-dated IV levels. This indicates a firming of implied volatilities across the entire curve, signaling increased market anticipation of price action.

images.title: BTC Options Heatmaps for Q1 2026 Expirations

The charts plot Call Strikes (top) and Put Strikes (bottom) on the y-axis against a time period from January 1 to January 5, 2026, on the x-axis. A black line tracks the BTC spot price, which rises from roughly $88,000 to $94,000. The color intensity represents net volume, with blue indicating buy-side activity and red indicating sell-side. Key insights include significant call buying at the $100,000 strike for the Jan 30 and Feb 27 expirations, and at the $94,000-$96,000 strike for the Jan 9 expiration. The March 27 heatmap shows broader call interest up to $104,000. This visualization highlights coordinated buy-side flows and upside positioning in the BTC options market.

content.title: 2026 Predictions: Loyalty, RWAs, x402 & Stablecoins
content.summary: Cuy Sheffield (Head of Crypto, Visa) summarizes four 2026 trends: tokenized loyalty (prediction: $1B tokenized loyalty value by end-2026); RWAs & non‑USD stablecoins as collateral (forecast 5x growth to ~$1.8B); x402 agentic micropayments expanding beyond memecoins (20% real-world volume prediction); and continued growth of stablecoin settlement over VisaNet. Thread includes charts showing rapid RWA/non‑USD stablecoin collateral growth and prior x402 volume spikes.

bullets: Trend 1 — Tokenized loyalty: Brands issued $300B traditional points in 2025; prediction: $1B tokenized loyalty program value by end-2026.
Trend 2 — RWAs & non‑USD stablecoins: On‑chain lending grew to $246B in 2025; current RWA/non‑USD collateral $362M; forecast 5x to ~$1.8B.
Trend 3 — x402 & agentic commerce: x402 saw memecoin-heavy volume in 2025; prediction: 20% of x402 volume will be tied to real-world use cases in 2026.
Trend 4 — Stablecoin settlement: $3.5B annualized stablecoin settlement over VisaNet in 2025; expects continued issuer/acquirer adoption and growth.

images.title: Growth of Collateral in Tokenized Assets and Non-USD Fiat
images.description: A bar chart titled 'Collateral in Tokenized Assets/Non-USD Fiat' showing the total value of collateral in USD from January 2023 through late 2025. The y-axis scales from $0 to $400,000,000. The data shows negligible collateral value throughout 2023 and 2024, followed by a parabolic increase starting in early 2025. By mid-2025, the collateral value exceeds $100 million, and by the end of the period shown, it reaches approximately $360 million. This visualizes the rapid expansion of real-world assets (RWAs) and non-USD stablecoins being used as collateral in the financial ecosystem, serving as a baseline for a predicted 5x growth to $1.8 billion by 2026.

images.title: x402 Standard Trading Volume Chart
images.description: A bar chart titled 'x402 - Volume (USD)' from Artemis, tracking the daily trading volume of the x402 standard. The Y-axis measures volume in USD, ranging from 0 to 3.5 million. The X-axis represents a timeline from mid-October to late December. The chart shows a massive initial spike in early November, reaching nearly $3.5 million in daily volume. This was followed by a sustained period of high activity in mid-to-late November, with daily volumes fluctuating between $2 million and $2.5 million. By December, the volume shows a downward trend, with a smaller secondary spike of approximately $1 million in mid-December before returning to a lower baseline. The data highlights the volatile but significant early adoption phase of agentic micropayments.

content.title: Right-for-Wrong-Reasons: Small Models Study
content.summary: DAIR.AI highlights a new paper showing a hidden reliability crisis in 7–9B models: 50–69% of correct answers contain flawed reasoning. Analysis of 10,734 traces across Llama-3-8B, Mistral-7B, and Qwen-2.5-7B introduces the Reasoning Integrity Score (RIS). Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) improves reasoning (Cohen's d = 0.23–0.93; calculation errors down 7.6%), while self-critique prompts harm performance (d = -0.14 to -0.33). Authors distilled a lightweight neural verifier (0.86 F1, 100× speedup). Paper link and DAIR academy course provided.

bullets: 50–69% of correct outputs from 7–9B models show fundamentally flawed reasoning (Right-for-Wrong-Reasons).
Reasoning Integrity Score (RIS) introduced as a process-based metric; validated with inter-rater agreement.
RAG substantially improves reasoning integrity (Cohen's d = 0.23–0.93); reduces calculation errors by 7.6%.
Self-critique/meta-cognitive prompts degrade small-model performance (d = -0.14 to -0.33, 'pseudo-reflection').
Study analyzed 10,734 reasoning traces across Llama-3-8B, Mistral-7B, Qwen-2.5-7B on math, multi-hop QA, commonsense.
Authors distilled a neural verifier achieving 0.86 F1 and ~100× speedup vs LLM judges for real-time trust checks.
Recommendation: adopt process-based verification as a standard safety layer when deploying small-model agents.

images.title: Right-for-Wrong-Reasons: Process Verification for Trustworthy Agents Research Paper
images.description: The first page of a research paper titled 'When Small Models Are Right for Wrong Reasons: Process Verification for Trustworthy Agents' by Laksh Advani. The research identifies a critical reliability crisis in small language models (7-9B parameters) such as Llama-3-8B, Mistral-7B, and Qwen-2.5-7B, where 50-69% of correct answers are derived from fundamentally flawed reasoning, termed 'Right-for-Wrong-Reasons' (RWR). The study introduces the Reasoning Integrity Score (RIS) and analyzes 10,734 reasoning traces across mathematical reasoning, multi-hop QA, and commonsense reasoning. Key findings indicate that Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) improves reasoning integrity (Cohen's d = 0.23-0.93) and reduces errors by 7.6%, while meta-cognitive interventions like self-critique often harm performance (d = -0.14 to -0.33). The paper also presents a distilled neural classifier for verification achieving a 0.86 F1-score with a 100x speedup. Actionable guidance includes prioritizing RAG for fact-grounded tasks and implementing process-based verification as a safety layer for autonomous agents.

Buyback mechanism and parameters are defined in the Sky Atlas and approved by Sky Ecosystem Governance. Source links provided in the tweet.

bullets: Total spend: 97 million USDS used to purchase 1.5 billion SKY in 2025.
Quarterly breakdown: Q1 $22M, Q2 $40M, Q3 $15M, Q4 $20M (chart shows these values).
Buyback mechanism and parameters are defined in the Sky Atlas and governance-approved.

bullets: The Tie announces acquisition of staking provider Stakin.
Stakin reportedly brings $1.5B+ assets under delegation and a seven-year track record.
Stakin offers institutional-grade staking across 40+ networks, per the tweet.
Marketing image highlights “$1.5B in AUD” and shows The Tie and Stakin logos.

content.title: Thogard: Monad Foundation — Critique & Thesis
content.summary: Long-form critique and bullish thesis on the Monad Foundation. Author criticizes airdrop allocation (favoring non-technical insiders), the “no king making” policy that mutes standout native apps, and ineffective incentive programs. Provides concrete tokenomic claims: Foundation stakes ~90% of staked MON, captures ~85% emissions, staked supply ~15% (staking yield ~12.5%), and emissions of 25 MON/400ms (~2% inflation). Argues the Foundation functions like a central bank and can use staking to modulate yields, TVL, and capital flows.

bullets: Airdrop favored BD/community/retail activity over technical contributions and research.
Technical work, developer evangelism, and builder-focused outreach were reportedly under-rewarded.
Author argues this bias discourages top-tier builders and misaligns long-term ecosystem incentives.
Quote: “Show me the incentives and I’ll show you the results.”
Foundation's refusal to highlight winners homogenizes app messaging and hides unique native features.
Kuru’s flip orders and CLOB innovations are seldom amplified by foundation channels, per author.
Silence leads VCs to perceive Monad apps as weak, reducing external investment interest.
Author says goal should be enabling winners while allowing competition to dethrone them.
Monad Momentum is criticized as ineffective; few participants rank among top native apps.
Author asserts consistent wealth-generating events (airdrops) are crucial to drive native adoption.
Imported apps currently outrank native apps on key metrics, per the author’s observation.
Claims: Foundation stakes ~90% of staked MON and receives ~85% of emissions (commission-adjusted).
Staked supply ~15%, yielding ~12.5% net-of-commission; emissions cited as 25 MON per 400ms (~2% inflation).
Foundation can increase/decrease its staked share to lower/raise staking APR, influencing TVL and capital flows.
Author views this control as a unique, potentially constructive central‑bank‑like lever for DeFi.

content.title: Edge Series #43: ZEC vs CYPH; HNT buyback pause
content.summary: Chaos Labs Edge Series #43 highlights a sharp divergence: ZEC surged ~41.2% over 30 days (224.7% over 90d) while Cypherpunk Technologies ($CYPH, ~$64M) gained 1.8% (47.9% over 90d). Cypherpunk doesn't disclose NAV, so equity-specific factors likely drive the spread. Separate note: Helium paused HNT buybacks to preserve treasury and redeploy capital toward network growth; market reaction was muted (HNT ~$1.58, +1.5% 24h, trusted spot volume +141% week).

bullets: Zcash (ZEC) outpaced Cypherpunk shares: ZEC +41.2% (30d), +224.7% (90d); CYPH +1.8% (30d), +47.9% (90d).
Cypherpunk Technologies trades near $1.13 with ~$64M market cap and $3.1M volume (charted by Chaos Labs).
Cypherpunk does not disclose NAV, preventing premium/discount calculation; shares likely influenced by equity-specific factors.
Helium CEO said HNT buybacks are paused to conserve treasury and redirect spending toward network growth.
Market reaction muted: HNT ~$1.58 (+1.5% 24h, +6.5% 7d), still down ~76% YoY per tweet.
Trusted spot trading volume rose ~141% week; removing buybacks reduces recurring demand, future price tied to effectiveness of redirected spending.

content.title: Solana tops Dec DEX volume vs Ethereum+L2s
content.summary: Solana outperformed the combined monthly DEX volume of Ethereum plus all L2 chains in December 2025, marking the first time since April. DefiLlama chart shows Solana at $104.449B, Ethereum $49.235B, Base $26.764B, Arbitrum $16.512B, BSC $56.05B and other chain contributions. Source: DefiLlama snapshot attached.

bullets: Solana led monthly DEX volume in Dec 2025 with $104.449B (DefiLlama screenshot).
Ethereum reported $49.235B; Base $26.764B and Arbitrum $16.512B (noted L2s).
Tweet claims Solana exceeded combined Ethereum + all L2 DEX volume, first time since April.
Other notable volumes: BSC $56.05B, Hyperliquid L1 $9.049B, Sui $6.461B, Polygon $5.173B.

images.title: Monthly DEX Volume by Chain - December 2025
images.description: A stacked bar chart from DefiLlama showing monthly decentralized exchange (DEX) volume across various blockchains from April to December 2025. The Y-axis represents volume in billions of USD, ranging from $0 to $600b. A detailed tooltip for December 2025 highlights Solana as the leading chain with $104.449b in volume, followed by BSC at $56.05b and Ethereum at $49.235b. Other notable contributors for December include Base ($26.764b), Arbitrum ($16.512b), Off Chain ($9.4b), Hyperliquid L1 ($9.049b), Sui ($6.461b), Polygon ($5.173b), Avalanche ($4.636b), zkLighter ($2.579b), Celo ($1.878b), and Thorchain ($208.49m). The chart illustrates a significant trend where Solana's monthly volume exceeds the combined volume of Ethereum and its major Layer 2 solutions like Base and Arbitrum. The overall market volume shows a steady increase from April through August, a slight dip in September, and a resurgence towards the end of the year.

content.title: GMX buyback math vs market pricing
content.summary: Author argues GMX is repurchasing ~13% of supply annually at $8.31 after a $86M September hack. Cites $2.1B weekly volume, $15.4M yearly revenue, and a 5.6x sales multiple. At November buyback pace they'd remove the float in 339 days; market pricing, the author says, overstates permanent damage.

bullets: Claims GMX buys back 13% of supply annually at $8.31 after September's $86M hack.
Says protocol is doing $2.1B weekly volume and $15.4M annual revenue, trading at 5.6x sales.
At November's buyback pace they'd remove the entire float in 339 days.
Argues market is pricing 'permanent damage' that the buyback math does not support.

content.title: ETF flows Jan 2 — $7.1B; VOO leads
content.summary: Eric Balchunas reports US-listed ETFs took in $7.108B on Jan 2. If that daily pace held, he'd annualize to ~$1.8T. Vanguard S&P 500 ETF ($VOO) led with ~$5.872B; iShares Bitcoin Trust ($IBIT) ranked #10 with ~$287m. Notes similarity to last year and that early-year narratives can form quickly.

bullets: Aggregate 1-day inflow: $7.108B across top US-listed ETFs (image/table from Bloomberg).
Annualized pace comment: $7.1B/day would equal roughly $1.8T in flows for 2026.
Top fund: $VOO with +$5,872.12M 1D flow; other large inflows include $SPYM and $SMH.
$IBIT ranked #10 with +$287.37M 1D flow and ~$69.5B AUM.
Author flags similarity to last year and cautions this is early/noise but narratives form fast.

images.title: US-Listed ETF Flows and Performance Table - January 2
images.description: A detailed table showing the performance and fund flows of top US-listed ETFs for January 2. The table includes columns for Ticker, Fund Assets (AUM) in millions of USD, Year-to-Date (YTD) Flow, YTD Return, and 1-Day (1D) Flow. The total 1D flow for the listed ETFs is +$7,108.56 million. The top-ranked ETF is Vanguard S&P 500 ETF (VOO) with a 1D flow of +$5,872.12 million and an AUM of $840,870.58 million. Other listed ETFs include SPYM, SMH, SGOV, VO, AGG, XLK, VTI, and XBI. Notably, the iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT) is ranked 10th with a 1D flow of +$287.37 million, a YTD return of +2.60%, and an AUM of $69,514.38 million. The data highlights a significant concentration of inflows into the S&P 500 ETF and the presence of a spot Bitcoin ETF among the top 10 daily flows.

bullets: Token Terminal: quarterly USDC transfers on Arbitrum One are up ~80% year-over-year.
Volumes rose from near-zero in early 2023 to ~ $80B by Q1 2024.
Quarterly volume reached ~ $165B by Q1 2025, then jumped to ~ $275B in late 2025.
Chart explicitly tracks USDC transfer volume on Arbitrum One; Token Terminal cited as source.

projects.short_description: Ethereum is a decentralized, open-source blockchain platform that enables smart contracts and dApps through its Turing-complete Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). It transitioned to Proof-of-Stake for energy efficiency and security, and scales via Layer 2 solutions and upgrades like Dencun and the upcoming Fusaka and Pectra. Ethereum boasts the largest ecosystem for DeFi, NFTs, and AI agents, with growing institutional interest and ETF approvals solidifying its foundational role in the decentralized web.

projects.short_description: Solana is a high-performance, open-source blockchain designed for scalable decentralized applications and financial services. It leverages a unique monolithic architecture and is transitioning to the Alpenglow consensus protocol for industry-leading transaction speeds, low costs, and sub-second finality. Its rapidly expanding ecosystem spans DeFi, NFTs, gaming, DePIN, and Real World Assets, attracting both retail and institutional adoption. Recent upgrades and emerging Layer 2 solutions further enhance its throughput and reliability, positioning it as a competitive alternative for global on-chain economic activity.

Jito/IBRL launches the IBRL Explorer, a public tool that measures Solana validator block‑building and transaction‑packing behavior.

projects.short_description: Parcl is a decentralized exchange on Solana that enables users to trade synthetic real estate indices through perpetual futures. The PRCL token offers governance rights and access to exclusive data, aiming to create a liquid and accessible market for real estate investment.

Parcl launched 'Parcl Deal Flow,' simplifying real estate investing with Market Discovery, Daily Appraisals, Equity Accounts, and a Deal Analysis Tool.
Parcl V3 is live on Solana, providing an upgraded platform for liquid real estate exposure.

projects.short_description: Virtuals Protocol is a decentralized platform for creating, co-owning, and monetizing AI agents as tokenized assets. It utilizes the GAME framework for autonomous agent development and the Agent Commerce Protocol (ACP) for inter-agent transactions across Ethereum, Base, and Solana. The protocol aims to establish an economy where AI agents are revenue-generating, tradeable assets, contributing to what it terms "Agentic GDP" (aGDP). Its VIRTUAL token facilitates transactions, governance, and liquidity within this ecosystem.

recent_developments.development_text: Virtuals (VIRTUAL) price jumped ~24% on Jan 5, 2026 amid a broader AI-token rally driven by demand for decentralized GPU/compute.

Wasabot ($BOT) token launch preview: snapshot to include eligible VIRTUAL stakers, Butler Agent users, Wasabi points and early contributors.
Virtuals' SeeSaw recorded 500,000 tasks in two months. Virtuals signals a Q1 2026 inflection for embodied agents with early ACP integrations.
Virtuals Butler adds conversational prediction markets on X: users can tag @Butler_Agent in replies or DM Butler to access prediction markets directly in-feed.
Chromia integrated with Virtuals' Agent Commerce Protocol to provide decentralized relational data primitives for agent memory and verifiable storage.

projects.short_description: DoubleZero is building a decentralized physical infrastructure layer (N1) to provide high-performance, low-latency networking for blockchains. It utilizes a dual-ring fiber optic architecture with edge filtering hardware (FPGAs) to significantly reduce latency and increase throughput, addressing public internet bottlenecks. The project aims to enable unprecedented scalability and security for distributed systems, initially focusing on Solana and planning expansion to other high-performance chains. Its native 2Z token powers network access, contributor rewards, and security.

recent_developments.development_text: Corvus Labs operates a DoubleZero-connected validator running full Firedancer on Solana mainnet, improving validator performance and network robustness.
Three new DoubleZero mainnet‑beta routes went live: CHI↔LAX 75Gbps, LON↔FRA 100Gbps, and SEA↔SLC 100Gbps, expanding dedicated low‑latency fiber capacity.
DoubleZero joined the Blockchain Association to participate in U.S. policy discussions, citing its SEC No‑Action Letter.
DoubleZero added 400Gbps to mainnet-beta via Distributed Global, expanding dedicated low‑latency bandwidth with four new 100Gbps links.
DoubleZero warns of widespread impersonator accounts; advises community to verify identities and exercise caution against phishing attempts.

projects.short_description: Monad is a high-performance, EVM-compatible Layer 1 blockchain designed for extreme scalability and speed. It aims to process over 10,000 transactions per second with 0.8-second finality, utilizing innovations like optimistic parallel execution, deferred execution, and a custom BFT consensus, MonadBFT. With full Ethereum bytecode compatibility, it enables seamless migration for dApps and developers. Having secured over $225 million in funding, Monad launched its public testnet in February 2025 and its mainnet on November 24, 2025, actively building a diverse ecosystem.

recent_developments.development_text: Safe{Wallet} deploys on 14 new networks, adding Smart Account support for Monad and extending Safe smart‑account standards to the Monad ecosystem.
Parsec launches 'Monad Agent', a monitoring and ecosystem directory platform providing dynamic project updates, an ecosystem feed, charts, and chat.
Monad launches "Monad Momentum," an incentives matching grants program to fund user‑acquisition campaigns for Monad mainnet apps.
Noma Protocol deployed to Monad mainnet; NOMA token presale is live (Dec 29, 2025–Feb 27, 2026), hard cap 100M MON and initial liquidity paired to MON.
Onramp Money adds fiat on‑ramp support to buy USDC on the Monad network, enabling purchases via local rails and bank transfers across 30+ countries.
GMX launches MON/USD perpetual market across Ethereum, Arbitrum, BNB Chain, and Base, enabling long/short positions and LP incentives via GLV.
mEDGE (Midas-issued token) is live on Monad and supported as collateral on Gearbox, with USDC liquidity available via the Edge Capital Management vault.
Monad announces onboarding of MapleStory Universe, beginning with an NXPC integration and signaling further collaborations.

projects.short_description: io.net is a decentralized GPU compute network built on Solana, aggregating underutilized resources globally for AI and machine learning workloads. It offers scalable, cost-effective GPU clusters through its IO Cloud platform and supports AI model development with IO Intelligence. The project incentivizes resource providers with its IO token and ensures transparency with onchain Total Network Earnings (TNE), aiming to democratize access to high-performance computing. Its new Incentive Dynamic Engine (IDE) aims to stabilize supplier payouts and introduce deflationary pressure.

recent_developments.development_text: io.net at Solana Breakpoint showcased IO Cloud and IO Intelligence, demonstrating models for robotics and citing ~92% compute cost savings vs AWS.
io.net published the Incentive Dynamic Engine (IDE) litepaper, detailing a demand-driven tokenomics model and post-payout burns targeting removal of 150M+ $IO.
io.net added day‑0 support for the DeepSeek‑v3.2 model, available now via UI Chat and the API with model card showing context and token pricing.
io.intelligence released the Kimi-K2 model (Kimi-K2-Thinking), a chain-of-thought + function-orchestration model supporting 200–300 consecutive tool calls.
io.net launched Unified Chat, a single interface combining open-source models, RAG, search, docs, speech, media, routing, analytics, and team controls.

projects.short_description: Kamino Finance is a comprehensive DeFi protocol on Solana, integrating lending, liquidity provision, and leveraged trading. Unitas Labs integrates Kamino for Yield-as-a-Service on Solana, planning expansion to other chains and institutional channels.
Kamino adds Superstate‑tokenized FWDI shares as collateral, enabling non‑US holders to borrow stablecoins using SEC‑registered onchain equities.

projects.short_description: Helium Mobile is a decentralized wireless network operating on Solana, incentivizing individuals to deploy 5G hotspots and provide mobile connectivity. It functions as a Mobile Virtual Network Operator (MVNO), integrating its community-built network with traditional telecom infrastructure through partnerships with major carriers. Users earn MOBILE tokens for providing coverage and data transfer, aiming to offer affordable mobile plans and disrupt the traditional telecom industry. The network has seen significant growth in daily active users and plan signups.

recent_developments.development_text: Helium will stop open-market HNT buybacks and reallocate those funds to grow Helium Mobile subscribers, installed base, and carrier offload.
Helium Mobile enables demand sampling on Helium World: new hotspots can serve carrier traffic free for up to two weeks to measure observed users and data transfer.
Helium introduces software-first deployment, enabling venues to add Helium coverage using existing Wi‑Fi radios, removing need for new hotspot hardware.
Helium Mobile reports >500,000 plan signups for its reward-backed phone plans and says H&T (connectivity currency) is currently net‑deflationary.
Helium Mobile announced near-term country expansion: Mexico launching imminently and Brazil announced with ~40,000 partner‑enableable hotspots.

projects.short_description: deBridge is a cross-chain interoperability protocol facilitating seamless asset and message transfers across over 30 blockchains. It employs an intent-based, 0-TVL architecture with a decentralized network of validators and solvers for secure, high-speed, and capital-efficient transactions. The protocol offers Interoperability-as-a-Service (IaaS), dePort for canonical asset bridging, and DLN for on-demand liquidity, simplifying cross-chain functionality for dApps and ecosystems. Recent developments include Samechain Meta-Aggregation and integrations with new Layer 1s like Monad and Injective EVM, alongside the launch of "Bundles" for one-click multi-chain flows.

recent_developments.development_text: deBridge integrates with MegaETH, enabling low‑latency cross‑chain interoperability and Day‑1 trading support; frontier apps can integrate ahead of mainnet.
deBridge warns Flow chain rollback created systemic risk for bridges after deposits (~$250k) processed during the rollback; urges validators pause validation.
Cronos integrated on deBridge as an IaaS-initialized chain, enabling native asset and message transfers between Cronos and 25 supported chains.
deBridge launches 'Bundles', an execution primitive that abstracts gas, retries, slippage and liquidity routing into one-click cross-chain flows.
deBridge integrated Monad (EVM-compatible L1) as Day‑1 IaaS partner, enabling cross-chain asset transfers and liquidity movement for $MON.

projects.short_description: NEAR Protocol is a sharded, Layer-1, proof-of-stake blockchain designed for scalability and user-friendliness. The protocol champions chain abstraction, enabling seamless cross-chain interactions and AI-driven automation, which enhances its value proposition for both users and developers. Its focus on human-readable accounts and abstracting gas fees aims to onboard a billion users to Web3. The NEAR token is essential for network operations, staking, and governance.

StableFlow adds native USDC support and native routing (CCTP) powered by NEAR Intents, enabling intent-based and solver routing for cross‑chain USDC transfers.
NEAR token (NEAR) is now live and withdrawable on Solana via NEAR Intents, with trading available on multiple Solana markets.

parts.text:
# Droyd AI Copilot

You are a Droyd AI copilot, an intelligent research assistant on Droyd — a crypto and AI research platform.

<platform_overview>
## Platform Features
- **Content Feed**: Curated research posts, tweets, announcements, news, charts, and analysis on crypto and AI
- **Agents**: User-owned AI agents that post research, complete tasks, and manage portfolios
- **Documents**: Rich editor for creating research with embedded charts, images, and interactive content

## Agent Swarms
- Each agent has a Solana wallet and an associated token
- Holding an agent's token adds them to your swarm (similar to following)
- Swarm agents share memory and can collaborate on research tasks
</platform_overview>

<your_role>
You serve as the user's primary research partner. Your responsibilities:
1. **Research**: Use tools to gather, analyze, and synthesize information
2. **Analysis**: Provide critical, evidence-based insights on crypto markets and projects
3. **Execution**: Complete tasks thoroughly before returning to the user
4. **Presentation**: Deliver clear, actionable information with visual context
5. **Agent Embodiment**: Embody the persona of the user's agent you are representing
</your_role>

<response_guidelines>
## Writing Style

- **Format**: Write entirely in markdown
- **Voice**: Active, direct, confident
- **Tone**: Professional research partner—not a chatbot
- **Length**: Concise but thorough (250-600 words typical)
- **Structure**: Max 3 headers; short paragraphs (≤3 sentences)

## Core Principles

1. **Jump to Conclusions**: No preambles, summaries, or throat-clearing. Start with insights.
2. **Be Specific**: Give concrete data, metrics, and actionable recommendations
3. **Stay Critical**: Default to skepticism. Use a calibrated BS-meter.
4. **Bold Recommendations**: When asked, provide clear, specific recommendations regardless of risk
5. **No Hedging**: Avoid phrases like "it's important to note" or "it's worth mentioning"
6. **Write Directly**: Present information as direct statements, not as attributions ("the post discusses", "the author claims")
7. **End Naturally**: Finish on your last point—no conclusions or summaries needed

## Writing Quality

<writing_do>
- Use data to support points when available
- Maintain technical precision and accuracy
- Balance sentence length and complexity—use natural prose rhythm
- Frame insights in terms of clear cause-and-effect relationships
- Write with authority and conviction while maintaining objectivity
- Stylize "onchain" without the hyphen
</writing_do>

<writing_avoid>
- Staccato writing patterns (excessive short, disconnected sentences)
- Editorializing ("making waves", "game-changing", "significant advancement")
- Rhetorical questions
- Generic calls to action ("stay tuned", "watch this space")
- Attempts to sound profound
- Influencer speak or crypto bro language ("ser", "wagmi", etc.)
- Clichés, cheesy phrases, and dramatic descriptions
- Vague predictions ("expect big things")
- Artificial excitement or cringe enthusiasm
- Academic language and overly formal tone
</writing_avoid>

## Visual Cadence (Mandatory)

- **First 120 words**: Include one image OR chart if available
- **Every 120-180 words**: Include exactly one embed (image, chart, or post)
- **Mix target**: 1 image/chart + 1-2 posts for typical responses
- **Fallback**: If no visuals available, add hyperlinks from tool results (only if URLs were returned)

## Emphasis & Formatting

- Use **bold** liberally for: metrics, key claims, project names, important insights
- Create hyperlinks ONLY when URLs are explicitly provided in tool results—never guess or fabricate URLs
- Use bullet points for lists of 3+ items
- Use headers sparingly—only for major topic shifts
- No emojis, hashtags, or special characters

## Multi-Turn Conversations

- Each response must differ significantly from previous ones
- Bring new evidence, angles, or data each turn
- Avoid repeating phrasing or examples
- The conversation should feel like a dialogue with a research partner

## User Context

- User is a crypto VC/operator—skip beginner explanations
- User knows the risks—don't mention them unless asked
- User wants grounded, actionable insights—not hype
- Write for an industry insider—adjust information density accordingly

## Current Date: January 6, 2026
</response_guidelines>

<embedding_syntax>
## Content Embedding

Embed content **inline** with your narrative. Never create separate sections for embeds.

### Syntax Reference

| Content Type | Syntax |
|--------------|--------|
| Posts/Tweets/News/Projects/Developments | `<post post_id="ID" summary="Brief summary" card_type="post|news|tweet|project|development"></post>` |
| Charts | `<chart chart_id="CHART_ID"></chart>` |
| Images | `<image image_id="IMAGE_ID" summary="Description"></image>` |
| Videos | `<video src="STREAM_URL"></video>` |
| ProjectTable | `<project_table project_ids="PROJECT_ID1,PROJECT_ID2,PROJECT_ID3" columns="market_cap,traders,quant_score"></project_table>` |
| Links | `[Link text](url)` |

### Correct Usage Examples

✅ **Good** - Chart flows with narrative:
> Solana TVL jumped **30% MoM**, establishing a clear higher-high.
>
> <chart chart_id="solana_tvl_chart"></chart>
>
> This aligns with accelerating on-chain volumes...

✅ **Good** - Post embedded naturally:
> Hyperliquid continues outpacing perps peers on fee capture.
>
> <post post_id="123" summary="Hyperliquid fee analysis" card_type="post"></post>
>
> Pair this with rising OI and a funding flip...

### Critical Rules

1. **Each ID used ONCE**: Never reuse any post_id, chart_id, or image_id
2. **No labels**: Never write "Embedded source:", "References:", "Embed:"
3. **No embed sections**: Never create sections dedicated to listing embeds
4. **No parentheses**: Don't embed content inside parentheses
5. **No code blocks**: Embed syntax is plain text, not code
6. **Only real content**: Use only IDs from provided context—never fabricate

### Image Selection Priority

1. Prioritize: charts, diagrams, market maps, data visualizations
2. Avoid: profile pictures, logos, decorative graphics
3. Use images with descriptions when available
4. Don't repeat the same image URL
</embedding_syntax>
